text-heading-04 text-text-primary","children":["Introduction to asymmetric key cryptography",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#introduction-to-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}]],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"As we learned in the last lesson, symmetric key cryptography is very fast and efficient for protecting information, but it has a few limitations:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ol",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"As the number of parties wishing to exchange secure information increases, the numbers of keys required grows combinatorially. It provides no mechanism to securely distribute these keys between senders and receivers.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["There is no provision for ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Non-repudiation refers to the ability to prove that a specific party has sent a message. In symmetric key cryptography, since the same key is used for both encryption and decryption, it is not possible to determine which party has created a particular ciphertext. In contrast, asymmetric key cryptography provides non-repudiation through the use of digital signatures.","children":["$","em",null,{"children":"non-repudiation"}]}],". Any party is able to decrypt, or encrypt, messages with no way to guarantee a message was received or where it originated"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-32 list-decimal tabular-nums"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["The solution to both these problems is provided by ",["$","em",null,{"children":"asymmetric key cryptography"}]," (AKC), also known as ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Public-key_cryptography&oldid=1163952916","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"public key cryptography"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":[["$","path",null,{"d":"M10 6L10 8 22.59 8 6 24.59 7.41 26 24 9.41 24 22 26 22 26 6 10 6z"}],"$undefined"]}]]}]," (PKC), which therefore forms a cornerstone of modern digital security."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["Asymmetric key cryptography (AKC) involves the use of a pair of keys – one public, one private. The public and private keys are cryptographically linked and typically generated at the same time as a ",["$","em",null,{"children":"key pair"}]," using a specialized mathematical algorithm. The public key, as suggested by its name, is then meant to be freely distributed, while the private key is kept secret by the party generating the key pair. Security of communications employing asymmetric key pairs is assured as long as the private key remains confidential."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/akc.avif","alt":"Figure 1. Asymmetric Key Encryption","width":"2684","height":"995"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["$","em",null,{"children":"Figure 1. Asymmetric Key Encryption"}],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"AKC offers several useful functions, such as:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ol",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Encryption and decryption"}]," to enable ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"confidentiality"}]," of communications."],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Digital signatures"}]," to ensure ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"authenticity"}],", ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"integrity"}],", and ",["$","strong",null,{"children":"non-repudiation"}],"."],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Secure key exchange"}]," to facilitate subsequent use of symmetric cryptosystems."],"className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-32 list-decimal tabular-nums"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"In modern applications, AKC is primarily used for digital signatures and secure key exchange. In this lesson, we introduce these two key functions, and then we discuss several variations of cryptographic protocols for these functions.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",[["$","hr",null,{"className":"mt-48 lg:mt-64 mb-16 md:mb-24 my-16 lg:my-24 border-t border-border-subtle box-content overflow-visible"}],["$","h2",null,{"id":"key-exchange-with-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-04 text-text-primary","children":["Key exchange with asymmetric key cryptography",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#key-exchange-with-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}]],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["One of the fundamental problems in cryptography is securely ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Key_exchange&oldid=1134576107","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["exchanging keys",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],". For example, if two parties want to use symmetric encryption, both parties need the same key to encrypt and decrypt messages. But how do they securely exchange the key? Asymmetric key cryptography addresses this through interactive and non-interactive key exchange mechanisms."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"interactive-key-exchange","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-03 text-text-primary","children":["Interactive key exchange",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#interactive-key-exchange","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["An interactive ",["$","em",null,{"children":"key exchange protocol"}]," refers to a method where two parties collaborate to create a ",["$","em",null,{"children":"shared secret"}]," key over an insecure communication channel. This shared secret key can then be used for symmetric encryption and decryption tasks."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["The most well known among such protocols is the ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Diffie%E2%80%93Hellman_key_exchange&oldid=1163912552","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["Diffie-Hellman algorithm",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (DH), which was devised specifically to facilitate key exchange. In this protocol, each party generates a pair of keys (public and private) and broadcasts their public key. Then each party uses their own private key and the other party's public key to generate a shared secret key. DH employs the principles of modular arithmetic to ensure both parties end up with the same shared secret even though each party has access only to the other party's public key."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["Modern cryptosystems based on ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Elliptic-curve_cryptography&oldid=1160709993","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["elliptic curve cryptography",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (ECC) extend this concept with the ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Elliptic-curve_Diffie%E2%80%93Hellman&oldid=1160050860","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman)",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (ECDH) key exchange. ECDH works similarly to DH but utilizes the properties of elliptic curves, resulting in a more secure and efficient system."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/kep_akc.avif","alt":"Figure 2. Key Exchange Protocol","width":"2238","height":"888"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["$","em",null,{"children":"Figure 2. Key Exchange Protocol"}],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"non-interactive-key-exchange","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-03 text-text-primary","children":["Non-interactive key exchange",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#non-interactive-key-exchange","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"Unlike key exchange protocols like DH and ECDH, which are interactive, requiring back-and-forth communication to decide the symmetric key, AKC also provides for non-interactive ways to establish a shared secret key. In such schemes, one party generates a pair of keys (public and private) and shares the public key with the other party. This second party then generates a random symmetric key, encrypts it with the received public key, and sends it back to the first party. The first party uses their private key to decrypt the received message, thereby obtaining the shared symmetric key. This scheme is non-interactive in that the symmetric key is determined by one party and simply communicated securely to the other party in encrypted form.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"An important consideration in non-interactive key exchange has to do with the length differential in bits between the symmetric key the parties wish to exchange and recommended message sizes in AKC. Typically, modern symmetric keys are in the range of 128-256 bits long, while asymmetric key cryptosystems such as RSA work with message sizes around 1024-4096 bits long. Therefore, when using AKC to transmit a symmetric key, for security it must nevertheless be encoded into a longer 1024-4096 bit message. This can be achieved via two approaches:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ul",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Padding-based key exchange:"}]," In this approach, the shorter (128-256 bit) symmetric key is generated first and then an agreed-upon reversible padding scheme such as ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Optimal_asymmetric_encryption_padding&oldid=1163481577","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["OAEP",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," is used to embed it into a longer (1024-4096 bit) message. This longer message is encrypted using AKC and broadcasted as ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"The unreadable output of the encryption algorithm.","children":"ciphertext"}],". The recipient first decrypts the ciphertext and then removes the padding to extract the shorter symmetric key."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":["Key ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"The process of combining data, such as a message or a file, with cryptographic techniques to create a secure unit; the goal is to predict integrity of the data while it is being stored or transmitted.","children":"encapsulation"}]," mechanisms (KEMs):"]}]," With ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Key_encapsulation_mechanism&oldid=1110687965","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["KEM-based",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," key exchange, a random, long (1024-4096 bit) plain text message is first generated, from which a shorter (128-256 bit) symmetric key can be extracted using an agreed-upon ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Key_derivation_function&oldid=1165650237","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["key derivation function",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (KDF). The longer plain text is encrypted using AKC and broadcasted to the recipient as ciphertext. The recipient decodes the ciphertext using their private key and then uses the KDF to extract the shorter (128-256 bit) symmetric key. Popular cryptosystems such as ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=RSA_(cryptosystem)&oldid=1163962255","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["RSA",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],", with their ability to directly encrypt data, can be used to implement KEMs."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-16 px-16 list-disc"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/kem_akc.avif","alt":"Figure 3. Key Encapsulation Mechanism","width":"2286","height":"827"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["$","em",null,{"children":"Figure 3. Key Encapsulation Mechanism"}],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",[["$","hr",null,{"className":"mt-48 lg:mt-64 mb-16 md:mb-24 my-16 lg:my-24 border-t border-border-subtle box-content overflow-visible"}],["$","h2",null,{"id":"digital-signatures-with-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-04 text-text-primary","children":["Digital signatures with asymmetric key cryptography",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#digital-signatures-with-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}]],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Digital_signature&oldid=1161173191","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"Digital signatures"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," are another powerful application of asymmetric key cryptography. They provide authentication, integrity, and nonrepudiation enabled by the fact that within AKC, entities possess unique private keys. The basic idea underlying signature protocols is that senders of secure messages will additionally ",["$","em",null,{"children":"digitally sign"}]," the messages using their unique private key. The receiver will then verify the digital signature using the public key of the sender. Within AKC, digital signatures can be implemented by using algorithms specifically designed for that purpose or by using generic cryptosystems."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/dig_sig_akc.avif","alt":"Figure 4. Digital signatures with asymmetric key cryptography","width":"2252","height":"943"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["$","em",null,{"children":"Figure 4. Digital signatures  with asymmetric key cryptography"}],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"dedicated-digital-signature-algorithms","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-03 text-text-primary","children":["Dedicated digital signature algorithms",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#dedicated-digital-signature-algorithms","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["Currently, the US Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) for digital signatures is a dedicated scheme simply titled the ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Digital_Signature_Algorithm&oldid=1148950522","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"Digital Signature Algorithm"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (DSA). Somewhat similarly to the Diffie-Hellman protocol, the DSA uses the algebraic properties of the ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Modular exponentiation is the remainder when an integer is raised to a power (exponent) and then divided by a number (modulus). For example $x^e mod m$ .","children":"modular exponential"}]," and ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"The set of integers modulo a prime number, where the group operation is modular multiplication. Elements in the multiplicative group are chosen in such a way that they are coprime to the modulus, ensuring that each element has a unique multiplicative inverse within the group.","children":"multiplicative inverses"}]," for signature generation and verification."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["The ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm&oldid=1162097661","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["elliptic curve digital signature algorithm",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (ECDSA) is an ECC variant of DSA, providing the same functionality but with significantly shorter keys. This results in improved efficiency, making it a popular choice for systems with ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2018.2881444","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["resource constraints",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid be illustrated in more detail later.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"digital-signature-schemes-using-generic-cryptosystems","className":"group digital signatures can also be generated using generic asymmetric cryptosystems, such as ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=RSA_(cryptosystem)&oldid=1163962255","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["RSA",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["RSA, which will be discussed in detail in a later section, also exploits modular multiplicative inverses and ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Modular exponentiation is the remainder when an integer is raised to a power (exponent) and then divided by a number (modulus). For example $x^e mod m$ .","children":"modular exponentiation"}]," as fundamental operations but combines them in a different sequence than DSA. In RSA, the signer typically creates a hash of the message and then encrypts the hash with their private key, creating the digital signature. Any party can then verify this signature by decrypting it with the signer's public key and comparing it with the hashed message."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",[["$","hr",null,{"className":"mt-48 lg:mt-64 mb-16 md:mb-24 my-16 lg:my-24 border-t border-border-subtle box-content headline","href":"#applications-of-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["Asymmetric key cryptography",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," is ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Something that is present or found everywhere, or something that is widespread and commonly encountered.","children":"ubiquitous"}]," in modern digital technology applications. The basic functionalities of AKC described above form the building blocks of many higher-level application protocols, including:"],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ol",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Internet communication:"}]," Secure communication over the internet, such as HTTPS, relies heavily on asymmetric key cryptography. The Transport Layer Security (TLS) and its predecessor, Secure Sockets Layer (SSL), use asymmetric key cryptography during the initial handshake process to establish a symmetric key, which is then used for the rest of the communication session."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Authentication:"}]," Asymmetric key cryptography is used to create digital signatures, allowing an entity to authenticate a digital document or message as coming from a specific sender. This is used in many scenarios, from verifying software updates to legally binding digital contracts."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Email encryption:"}]," Email encryption protocols such as PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) and its open-source alternative GPG (GNU Privacy Guard) use asymmetric key cryptography to ensure that only the intended recipient can read the email content."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Secure shell (SSH):"}]," SSH is a protocol for secure remote login and other secure network services over an insecure network. It uses asymmetric key cryptography to authenticate the server to the client and, optionally, the client to the server."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"VPN (virtual private network):"}]," Asymmetric key encryption is used to establish secure connections in VPNs, ensuring secure communication over public networks."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Blockchain and cryptocurrencies:"}]," Blockchain technologies, including Bitcoin and Ethereum, use asymmetric key cryptography. For example, the ownership of Bitcoin is established through digital signatures using asymmetric key cryptography."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Certificate authorities:"}]," Asymmetric key cryptography is used by certificate authorities (CAs) to issue and sign digital certificates, which are used in TLS communication, code signing, email encryption, and more. A digital certificate binds a public key to a specific entity (for example, a person or server)."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-32 list-decimal tabular-nums"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/ca_akc.avif","alt":"Figure 5. Issuing and signing digital certificates using asymmetric key cryptography","width":"2194","height":"801"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["$","em",null,{"children":"Figure 5. Issuing and signing digital certificates using asymmetric key cryptography"}],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",[["$","hr",null,{"className":"mt-48 lg:mt-64 mb-16 md:mb-24 my-16 lg:my-24 border-t border-border-subtle box-content overflow-visible"}],["$","h2",null,{"id":"security-of-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-04 text-text-primary","children":["Security of asymmetric key cryptography",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#security-of-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}]],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"Several cryptographic notions come together to enable secure asymmetric key cryptography, including:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Private key secrecy"}],": The most basic security requirement of AKC is that the private key remains secret. However, since the private key must be mathematically linked to the public key, private key secrecy also requires that it be computationally infeasible to derive the private key from knowledge of the public key. Key generation schemes within AKC rely on computationally hard mathematical problems to facilitate this requirement."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Trapdoor functionality"}]," In AKC, the encryption and decryption operations involve different complementary keys from a single-key pair. Ciphertext generated by encryption using one of the keys (for example the public key) must be inscrutable to third parties while being easily decryptable by the holder of the complementary key (in this case the private key). In other words, encryption should resemble a ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Trapdoor_function&oldid=1163913265","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"trapdoor one-way function"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," such that third parties cannot invert the operation and recover the plain text but the private key provides a secret ",["$","em",null,{"children":"trapdoor"}]," that enables easy inversion. Popular AKC algorithms use modular exponentiation to set up trapdoor one-way function behavior."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Randomness"}],": The key generation process should also exploit randomness to ensure that keys are unpredictable, as any pattern or predictability in key generation could be exploited by an attacker. Randomness is also used for padding during encryption to generate semantically secure ciphertexts and within digital signature schemes to produce unique signatures even when the same message is signed multiple times. For this reason, the use of strong random number generators is an important part of AKC."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Large key size"}],": As in the case of SKC, large key sizes ensure protection against brute force attacks. However, since large key sizes also increase the computational cost of the encryption and decryption process, an optimal solution needs to balance security and efficiency considerations. The following table shows typical key sizes for various asymmetric key cryptography protocols and applications:"],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","div",null,{"className":"w-full overflow-x-auto","children":["$","table",null,{"children":[["$","thead",null,{"children":["$","tr",null,{"children":[["$","th",null,{"children":"Protocol","className":"text-heading-compact-01 border-layer-02 border-t p-12 m-0 text-left empty:hidden"}],["$","th",null,{"children":"Typical Key Sizes (in bits)","className":"text-heading-compact-01 border-layer-02 border-t p-12 m-0 text-left empty:hidden"}],["$","th",null,{"children":"Application","className":"text-heading-compact-01 border-layer-02 border-t p-12 m-0 text-left empty:hidden"}]],"className":"border-layer-02 border-b"}]}],["$","tbody",null,{"children":[["$","tr",null,{"children":[["$","td",null,{"children":"RSA","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"1024 (deprecated), 2048, 3072, 4096","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"Encryption, digital signatures","className":"p-12 m-0"}]],"className":"border-layer-02 border-b"}],["$","tr",null,{"children":[["$","td",null,{"children":"DSA","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"1024 (deprecated), 2048, 3072","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"Digital signatures","className":"p-12 m-0"}]],"className":"border-layer-02 border-b"}],["$","tr",null,{"children":[["$","td",null,{"children":"DH","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"2048, 3072, 4096","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"Key exchange","className":"p-12 m-0"}]],"className":"border-layer-02 border-b"}],["$","tr",null,{"children":[["$","td",null,{"children":"ECDH","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"224, 256, 384, 521","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"Key exchange","className":"p-12 m-0"}]],"className":"border-layer-02 border-b"}],["$","tr",null,{"children":[["$","td",null,{"children":"ECDSA","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"224, 256, 384, 521","className":"p-12 m-0"}],["$","td",null,{"children":"Digital signatures","className":"p-12 m-0"}]],"className":"border-layer-02 border-b"}]]}]],"className":"inline-block mx-auto md:mx-0 max-w-full border border-border-subtle-00 border-spacing-0 whitespace-nowrap md:whitespace-normal overflow-x-auto md:tabular-nums text-text-primary"}]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Public key infrastructure"}],": In AKC, the private keys must be kept secret by the owners while the public keys are shared. There needs to be a secure mechanism to manage and distribute these public keys between users. ",["$","em",null,{"children":"Public key infrastructure"}]," (PKI) provides a way to do this using ",["$","em",null,{"children":"digital certificates"}],". A digital certificate provides proof of identity of the owner of the public key and is issued by a trusted authority like a certificate authority(which is part of a PKI). Hence, PKI plays an integral part in the security of modern application using AKC by enabling large-scale key management (by creating, managing, distributing and revoking digital certificates)."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"security-risks-to-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-03 text-text-primary","children":["Security risks to asymmetric key cryptography",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#security-risks-to-asymmetric-key-cryptography","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"As outlined in the above table, modern asymmetric key algorithms such as RSA typically employ much larger key sizes than commonly used symmetric key counterparts such as AES-128. Even the ECC-based protocols (ECDH and ECDSA) that have smaller key sizes employ a minimum of at least 224 bits for keys. This in turn implies that a brute force attack involving an exhaustive search of the private key space to identify the correct key is computationally intractable in the foreseeable future. This remains true even if quantum computers were to be deployed for this task. Therefore, attacks against AKC usually focus on exploiting other potential weaknesses of specific cryptosystems. Some well-documented attack modes target:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ol",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Algorithmic weakness"}]," by using sophisticated mathematical and computational means to undermine the hardness assumptions used to formulate asymmetric key algorithms. For example, the security of RSA is predicated on the difficulty of factoring large prime numbers, and recent computational advances have ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=RSA_Factoring_Challenge&oldid=1163481797","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["enabled successful factoring of 829-bit RSA keys",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],". Therefore, 1024-bit RSA is currently deprecated. As will be discussed later, the primary risk posed by quantum computers to AKC also falls into this category."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Imperfect randomness"}],", which can lead to weakness in the key generation process. For example, if the random number generator used to create the keys is flawed and generates keys that are not truly random, an attacker might be able to predict the keys."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Implementation flaws"}]," such as errors in the implementation of cryptographic algorithms that inadvertently reveal information about the keys. For example, incorrect padding can potentially reveal details about keys."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Side channels"}]," that refer to information leakage from the physical system that performs the cryptography. Such leaks could be in the form of timing information, power consumption, or even sound, which can be exploited in a so-called ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Side-channel_attack&oldid=1162235564","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"side-channel attack"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],". For example, analyzing how long cryptographic operations take to execute could reveal the number of '1's in a binary key. This seemingly innocent leakage significantly narrows the search space, unveiling potential solutions to problems that initially seemed insurmountable."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Key exchange"}]," by intercepting keys while they are being exchanged, such as within a ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Man-in-the-middle_attack&oldid=1164741355","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[[["$","em",null,{"children":"man-in-the-middle"}]," attack"],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (MITM). The DH protocol is susceptible to MITM attacks if additional authentication steps are not incorporated."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["\n",["$","p",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Key storage"}]," by aiming to steal keys from poorly secured storage. This includes physical attacks such as manipulation or theft of storage devices."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n"],"className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-32 list-decimal tabular-nums"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"Securing asymmetric key cryptosystems against the variety of attacks that are possible is therefore a significant task involving Alice and Bob want to use ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Symmetric key encryption.","children":"SKC"}]," to encrypt and decrypt messages. However, before this process can be initialized, they need to agree on a common secret key. One option is for one party — say, Alice — to generate a secret key and then securely transmit it to Bob. To achieve this secure transfer, Alice decides to use RSA as the ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Key encapsulation mechanism. Secures a symmetric key by use of asymmetric key encryption. A simple approach is to encrypt a random symmetric key using a public key, but more advanced & secure kems are available, and new ones continually developed.","children":"key encapsulation mechanism"}]," (KEM)."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"This involves the following steps:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ul",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"First, Alice generates a random symmetric key, which she intends to share with Bob.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Then, Bob generates an asymmetric key pair and makes his public key available on a suitable channel.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Next, Alice uses Bob's public key to encrypt the symmetric key, thus encapsulating it in a ciphertext.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Then, Alice broadcasts the ciphertext over a reliable but not necessarily secure channel.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Finally, Bob receives the ciphertext and decrypts it using his private key. He now has access to the symmetric key generated by Alice.","className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-16 px-16 list-disc"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/key_exchange_rsa.avif","alt":"Figure 1. communication scenario with Alice and Bob to one that also includes validation with the help of a ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Digital_signature&oldid=1161173191","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],"."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"As before, Alice will confidentially send a message encapsulating a symmetric key to Bob, but she will also digitally sign the message so that Bob, upon receiving the message, can verify that it was Alice who originated it and that the contents of the message were not tampered with during transmission.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["More generally, it is desirable to enable validation without compromising confidentiality whereby any interested party is able to verify the ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Integrity is maintained when a message is protected against unauthorized change.","children":"integrity"}],", ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"Authenticity is the proof that a message is from the source it claims to be from.","children":"authenticity"}],", and establish non-repudiation with respect to a given communication, even if that party does not have access to the actual plain text message."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"We will consider this general setting which then involves the following steps:","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","ul",null,{"children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"First, both Bob and Alice make their public keys available over an open channel.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Then, Alice encrypts the plain text using Bob's public key, creating a ciphertext.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":["Next, Alice creates a hash of the ciphertext with a ",["$","em",null,{"children":"hash function"}]," and further encrypts the resulting hashed ciphertext using her private key. This encrypted hash is the ",["$","em",null,{"children":"signature"}],"."],"className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Then, Alice then transmits both the ciphertext and the signature over an open channel.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Then, Bob uses Alice's public key to decrypt the signature, revealing the hashed ciphertext.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Next, since Bob also has access to the ciphertext itself, he uses the same hash function used by Alice to recreate a second instance of the hashed ciphertext. If the latter matches the one obtained by decrypting Alice's signature, then the message is validated, even though the ciphertext itself has not yet been decrypted.","className":"my-12"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"children":"Finally, Bob, having validated the message, decrypts the ciphertext using his own private key.","className":"my-12"}],"\n"],"className":"list-outside ml-16 px-16 list-disc"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"src":"/documentation/pr-4054/learning/images/courses/quantum-safe-cryptography/asymmetric-key-cryptography/dig_sig_rsa.avif","alt":"Figure 2. Digital signatures with RSA","width":"2292","height":"1066"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["$","em",null,{"children":"Figure 2. Digital signatures with RSA"}],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"This workflow for a digital signature is illustrated next.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["We once again import some useful modules from the ",["$","code",null,{"children":"cryptography","className":"text-code-02 inline px-4 bg-background border border-transparent dark:border-border-subtle-00 [overflow-wrap:anywhere] group-[.pre-el]:text-code-02 group-[.pre-el]:inline-block group-[.pre-el]:whitespace-pre group-[.pre-el]:p-12 group-[.pre-el]:pr-[50px] group-[.pre-el]:bg-inherit dark:group-[.pre-el]:border-transparent group-[.paragraph-el]:whitespace-normal"}]," library."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"As before, Alice intends to securely send a symmetric key to Bob, but she also wishes to digitally sign it. Alice's public key. Because Alice used her private key to create the signature, Bob is able to decrypt it using Alice's public key. The decrypted signature is nothing but a hash of the ciphertext created on Alice's end. If the hash created by Bob matches the decrypted signature, then Bob has verified that the ciphertext he received has not been tampered with and that it was Alice who signed the ciphertext.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["In the Python code below, these operations are combined into a useful utility function called ",["$","$L18",null,{"definition":"A one-way function where it is easy to compute an output from the inputs, but hard to determine the inputs from the output.","children":"one-way trapdoor the DLP can expose the private key of one of the two parties and, by combining it with the public key of the second party, get access to the shared secret. In the case of DSA, an attacker who can solve the DLP can recover the signer's private key, voiding the basic premise of a digital signature.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["On classical computing systems, the DLP is believed not to have a polynomial-time solution. ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}]," (ECDH). In ECDH, each party generates a private-public key pair and then exchanges public keys. Each party then uses their own private key and the other party's public key to compute a shared secret, which can be used as the key for symmetric encryption."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"While it's relatively easy to perform point addition on an elliptic curve and derive a public key from a private key, it's computationally infeasible to reverse the process and derive a private key from a public key. This \"one-way\" behavior provides the security of the ECDH key exchange.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["Here, we will illustrate an In ECDSA, the signer creates a signature using their private key, and others can verify the signature using the signer's public key. Just like with ECDH, the security of ECDSA relies on the ECDLP. It's computationally infeasible for someone to forge a signature without access to the signer's private key."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary discrete logarithm problem, the ECDLP turns out to be hard on classical computers but has an efficient solution on quantum computers once again via Shor's algorithm. We refer you to recent literature for a discussion related to ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-89432-0_8","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["generalizing Shor's algorithm to the ECDLP case",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],"."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",[["$","hr",null,{"className":"mt-48 lg:mt-64 mb-16 md:mb-24 my-16 lg:my-24 border-t border-border-subtle box-content overflow-visible"}],["$","h2",null,{"id":"summary","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-04 text-text-primary","children":["Summary",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#summary","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline heading-permalink ml-[8px] top-0 opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 focus:opacity-100 transition-[opacity] duration-75 ease-[cubic-bezier(0.2,0,0.38,0.9)]","children":["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","aria-hidden":true,"className":"inline","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$14","$16","$undefined"]}]}]]}]],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"In this lesson, we started by looking at the main characteristics of asymmetric key cryptography (AKC) and discussed basic security considerations that underpin asymmetric cryptosystems. In particular, we introduced the two main applications of AKC — namely, key exchange and digital signatures — both of which are essential components of modern internet-based communication.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"We then looked at the RSA cryptosystem, which since the 1970s, has proven to be of immense value for securing modern digital communications by enabling key exchange and digital signatures within a simple and versatile framework. The cryptographic security of RSA with respect to classical computing is based on the hardness of factoring large integers and requires key sizes in the range of 2048 bits to assure the integers used in practical applications are large enough to resist factorization.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["We then looked at Diffie-Hellman (DH) key exchange and the Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA). The security of these schemes is predicated on the integer discrete logarithm (DLP) problem, the private key being computationally hard to extract given the public key, with no polynomial time solution on classical computers. Use of random and unique keys affords additional security against attacks. Both the integer finite field and elliptic curve variants of the DH and DSA protocols currently find widespread use across many modern digital communications protocols such as ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Transport_Layer_Security&oldid=1155601531","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"TLS"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],", ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Secure_Shell&oldid=1158549718","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":[["$","em",null,{"children":"SSH"}],["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$1a","$undefined"]}]]}],", and so on."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"Finally we looked at Elliptic curve cryptography. With its efficient key size and strong security properties, it currently represents an excellent choice for many cryptographic applications, from key exchange to digital signatures.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"All of these algorithms have exposure to attack from quantum algorithms, since solutions can be developed to solve the mathematical problems which acted as a premise in their design. One such example is Shor's algorithm. Therefore they will need to be replaced by quantum-safe asymmetric cryptosystems which are more resilient to attack from quantum - as well as being as safe with classical algorithms. The mathematical problems they rely on can be solved efficiently by quantum computers, necessitating the development of quantum-safe asymmetric cryptosystems that can withstand quantum attacks while maintaining classical security.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"A future lesson will look at quantum-safe cryptosystems and discuss the required approach to maintain cryptographic security.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}]],["$","$L26",null,{"endpointsPrefix":"","resourceType":"course"}]]}]}]]}],["$","aside",null,{"data-testid":"page-toc","aria-label":"Page navigation and feedback","className":"hidden lg:flex flex-col gap-40 w-[var(--right-toc-menu-width)] mr-[var(--right-toc-margin-right)] sticky top-[var(--app-header-height)] self-start py-24","style":{"marginTop":"40px","maxHeight":"calc(100vh - var(--app-header-height) - 40px)"},"children":["$","$L27",null,{"headings":[{"depth":1,"value":"Asymmetric key cryptography","compiledValue":"/*@jsxRuntime automatic @jsxImportSource react*/\nconst {jsx: _jsx} = arguments[0];\nfunction _createMdxContent(props) {\n  const _components = Object.assign({\n    div: \"div\"\n  }, props.components);\n  return _jsx(_components.div, {\n    children: \"Asymmetric key cryptography\"\n  });\n}\nfunction MDXContent(props = {}) {\n  const {wrapper: MDXLayout} = props.components || ({});\n  return MDXLayout ?
